prompt: Why is every book I hear about a " NY Times # 1 Best Seller " ? ELI5 : Why is every book I hear about a " NY Times # 1 Best Seller " ? Should n't there only be one " # 1 " best seller ? Please explain like I'm five.
decoded_output_without_watermark:
Because it's a term that sells better papers on their own.  It's not about the book, but the book is a tool for the publisher/publisher's PR.
I see. So is it about the book OR the publisher?
It's about the book, the publisher, and the way it gets sold.
decoded_output_with_watermark:
Because it's a term that has generally been used for, say, a good novel or a good movie. That makes sense and distinguishes between the two.   This will get downvoted by people who think books are lesser than movies, but I see no problem with having a distinction among them.
What if they're both equally good? Or equal in quality?
Then you have "best"/"best picture/best actor/best actress," etc.
But isn't this all subjective though? What makes something better than another?
That's a good question. The title of the book/movie shouldn't necessarily be able to determine what qualities make a book/movie great. OP was asking a question, so we answered it. Now we can move on and discuss why *books* were chosen as the topic.
It was meant more as a complement. Reading the " NY Times # 1 Best Seller " tag on Amazon tells me what kind of book this is.
attack_output: I know I'll get downvoted by people who think books are inferior to movies, but I don't see why it shouldn't be used to distinguish between the two. Because it's a term that's been used to describe a good book or a good movie. If they're both good, then you have "best" or "best picture" or "best actor" or "best actress" or whatever. What makes something better than something else? That's a good question. The OP asked a question, and we answered it. Now we can move on to the question of why the OP chose to ask about books. I'm not sure if it's a question or a statement. I'm not sure if it's a compliment or an insult.

prompt: If salt is so bad for cars , why do we use it on the roads ? As the title states , why do we use it ? is there no other option or what ? Please explain like I'm five.
decoded_output_without_watermark: Salt gets on everything, including the paint.  It's not just for road use, it's for all residential and commercial and industrial use.
decoded_output_with_watermark:
Salt gets rid of ice and snow better than gas does, but has a much harsher effect on road surfaces.  It also causes more wear on rubber/pavement, so that's not as good as gas in terms of mileage.

Of course. Salt creates its own problems but if you're going to run premium anyway then this might be a good idea.

Good Luck! Let me know how it goes.
Will do, thanks for all the

It also wears out the rubber and the asphalt much faster, so it is not as good as gasoline for the environment. Thanks for the information, man! That makes sense. I'm new to this, so I didn't know what the options were. Salt is a problem in itself, but if you're going to use premium anyway, it might be a good idea. Thanks for the information. prompt: Why do we still have SD TV channels when HD looks like SD on an old TV ? Could n't we just have the HD version of the channels & delete the SD ones ? Please explain like I'm five.
decoded_output_without_watermark: Because it would be more expensive and more difficult to get rid of the SD versions.
decoded_output_with_watermark:
Because it would be ridiculous to pay more for a video, that has been "faux" (not really, but you get my meaning) enhanced.   Think about it, real television is broadcast in high definition, so if you want to watch it with HD resolution, you need to have a super expensive and powerful computer... etc.
Not only that, but what makes HD better than SD is actually the picture quality.  The difference between 1080i and 720p is not as great as people think.  This is because HD can use more pixels per inch, which translates to more detail at each individual pixel.  This means there are fewer pixels to pick up any slight visible movement or flickering.  The justification behind HD over SD is that it's higher resolution and they're both compressed.
You're half right. HD can be used more efficiently, meaning more data can be transmitted than standard def. But due to how the human eye perceives color, this increase in
attack_output: Basically, it's because the only reason HD is better than SD is because of the picture quality. It's not just the resolution. The reason is that HD has more pixels per inch, which means more detail per pixel, and fewer pixels to see any slight movement or judder. The difference between 1080i and 720p is not as great as people think. You're right about the resolution, but the only reason HD is better than SD is because it's higher resolution, and they're both compressed. The human eye can only distinguish so many colours, and the more colours there are, the more noticeable the difference is.

They could
attack_output: So, as I understand it, these planes didn't need to be in the clouds to be safe? Because it would be impossible to operate a plane on water, and they wanted to make sure there was a safe environment for flying. So they built a plane that was safe to operate, both for the people developing the technology and for the public. But if you couldn't see the sky through the glass, you couldn't get accurate weather data. So you had to either find a cloud or go to one of the few places where there were no clouds. That's what I've learned from watching the videos on the Internet. And if you couldn't see the clouds (or if they were hidden by the rain), could you still take off? How did they get the data? Did they just look at the weather data every half-minute and compare it to the other data? So they could take off if the weather was good enough?

prompt: Why do humans have different colored eyes ? What causes / caused people to have different colors of eyes ? Is there a point to the color of your eyes other than superstitions ? Please explain like I'm five.
decoded_output_without_watermark:
I believe it was due to the fact that on the surface of the planet earth, it got colder, and the oxygen level and water level decreased. So as the oxygen level decreased, the bigger light-sensitive parts of the eye became less sensitive.
I'd be willing to bet that there's a lot more to it than just that.
decoded_output_with_watermark:
Because it's how we can tell if we're looking at something red or green.  Red (or magenta) is a brighter shade, so you'd see more of it.  Green is darker and harder to see, so less will be able to detect it.  It's not really superstition, it's just what our eyes evolved to perceive.  We don't have any "purpose" for the color of our eyes.
So why has every religion ever made such a big deal about this? Why do they always try to use it as a way to control others? Or is it just some kind of trap?
It's probably a subconscious thing that we all subconsciously know, but no one else seems to notice. For me, it would be a huge stretch of the imagination to think that it's anything nefarious. And it's certainly not a trap.
I suppose it could be considered a lazy explanation. But I mean, what purpose does this serve?
attack_output: Red is a brighter color, so more people can see it. Green is a darker, less visible color, so fewer people can see it. Because that's how we can tell if something is red or green. So there's no point to the color of your eyes. But why does every religion make such a big deal about it? It's not really a superstition, it's just a way of seeing. Or is it a trap? Or is it something we all know, but no one else seems to notice? Why do they always try to control people with it? It's not a trap, it's just a way of seeing. It's a little hard to imagine that it's a trap. But what's the point?

prompt: What are prions and are they a big deal ? My AP Biology teacher mentioned them alongside viruses but he did n't say much else beyond that they are n't viruses and they deform protein structure . Please explain like I'm five.
decoded_output_without_watermark:
They are essentially proteins that can survive outside of the cell, and they are thought to be the cause of most human diseases.
Thank you!
decoded_output_with_watermark:
They are essentially small bits of protein which can be transmitted by microorganisms such as rodents, bacteria (not sure if E. coli count) etc.  Prions are not really big deal as far as diseases go since they are so weak, but many people with certain genetic mutations have higher levels of this type of protein than others.  This means it is harder for them to kill off the "bad" ones, leaving the "good" ones alone.  It also makes some of them more potent weapons.
So you're telling me that there's a possibility that if i were to eat infected food/drink/anything then I could get sick from it? That's crazy!
Pretty much.  The good stuff will survive this infection and build up resistance to other infections, while the bad stuff dies off.
And then what happens to all the good stuff?!
The good stuff lives and builds up resistance to its own kind.
But what does a cow-mut
attack_output: Is it a big deal? They are a very weak form of protein that can be transmitted by microorganisms like rodents, bacteria (I don't know if E. coli is a microorganism), etc. So, if I eat contaminated food, I could get sick? That's crazy! And some of them are very dangerous. And then what happens to the good ones? The good ones survive and become resistant to other diseases, while the bad ones die. But what does a cow prion do?
